WIORLD BANK Staff Working Paper No. 349 August 1979 0DJUSTMENT POLICIES AND PROBLEMS IN DEVELOPED COUNTRIES A Study of the Problems Created by, and Policies Toward, the Imports of Manufactures from Developing Countries A Background Study to the World Development Report, l919 This study examines the problem posed by the need to adjust to imports from developing countries. It- begins with an attempt to define the terms of adjustment and adjustment policy. The overall context within which adjust- ment has to occur is then discussed, and attention is drawn both to the un- favorable macroeconomic environment and to the bias against changes brought about by imports from developing countries. The theory of adjustment costs and their political implications is examined, followed by a review of the evidence on the exact impact of the exports of manufactures from developing countries and on the nature of the protectionist response as a political phe- nomenon. This leads to a definition of the possible forms and goals of adjust- ment policy. The effectiveness of existing policies is reviewed, immediately following a discussion of the relevant differences between major developed countries. Finally conclusions are drawn about what improved adjustment pol- might consist of in different country contexts. The study was prepared as a background paper to the second Forld_Dve - ment Report and is based on a review of some of the relevant literature and on interviews with officials in a number of governments and international organi- zations. The work was carried out between October 1978 and the beginning of February, 1979.  I. INTRODUCTION A. Scope of the Paper "Adjustment to change is a necessary condition of economic growth - indeed the growth process is -little more than a sequence of adjustments of this kind." (Blackhurst, Marian and Tumlir 1978 p.l.) L/ Virtually all economic policy has implications for the ability to adjust by ilts effect either on the purely economic aspects of change or on its political acceptability. /2 It would not be inappropriate to define the goal of economic policy as the determination of what to adjust to and how to adjust in the most efficient and socially acceptable manner. Even if adjustment is a central part of the process of economic evolution, it does not follow that policy decisions by Government are necessary. This depends on the extent to which economic change is considered to be within the boundaries of the political process. Laissez faire might be described as the first modern adjustment policy, and it makes unnecessary any political decision about the desirability of an economic change. /3 /1 This view of economic development is particularly clearly expressed by Schumpeter (1951, p.66) "Development.in our sense is then defined by the carrying out of new combinations." Scott (1976) has elaborated this way of looking at the process of growth. /2 The importance of social, economic, and political resistance to change is an essential part of Schumpeter's theory of- development and especially of the role of the entrepreneur (Schumpeter, 1951, pp. 86-9). /3 Of course, even in the heyday of laissez faire, Great Britain was the only country to adhere to free trade. In other cases, the tariff was used to impede change, when trade was the source of the pressure -for adjustment. However, in the 19th century protection in the now industrialized countries was at least as much a change-promoting as a change-retarding policy, being a major means -of infant-industry promotion.
 -2- However, even in such countries as the United States and West Germany, where the primacy of the market is still largely accepted, it is no longer possible for Government not to take a position on the desirability of a major economic change. The fundamental nature of the adjustment problem and its central place in the political process of the industrial democracies has several impli- cations for this paper. An obvious point is that the problem created by the need to adjust to trade, in general, and trade with the developing countries, in particular, must be seen in the context of the total impact of the forces of economic change. This is so, even though, as will be argued below, there are respects in which the problems created by trade are sui generis - at least politically- and thus merit special treatment. Furthermore, the difficulties are to a considerable extent political and our treatment must, therefore, consider both the political context and the likely political effect of various policy measures. In addition, many of the measures that are likely to make sense in the context of adaptation to trade are those appropriate to overall development. Industrial policies, for example, and action to improve the working of factor markets, while quite general in focus, are an important part of any process of adjustment to trade. However, it is necessary to go further: since political acceptabili-ty is crucial, policies to affect income distribution, income security and regional development will all have an effect on the adjustment to trade. Even macroeconomic policy will play a key role, since without full employment microeconomic adjustment will often be thwarted by the political process. However, macroeconomic policy, in turn, pre- supposes microeconomic flexibility, creating an intractable "chicken-and-egg" problem. /4 Finally, adjustment is an alternative to essentially defensive measures, and policy to achieve the former can be understood only in relation to /4 On this point, Blackhurst, Marian and Tumlir (1978, p.89) argue "Demand stabilization policies presuppose an economy in which competition ensures, through changing relative prices, a flexible adaptation of supply to changes in the pattern of demand."
 - 3- the characteristics and effects of the latter. This is particularly important, because some of the measures that masquerade, so to speak, as adjustment assis- tance are defensive measures by another name. Some narrowing of the scope is clearly necessary. For this reason, macroeconomic policy is largely ignored and other policies are examined almost entirely from the point of view of their effect on adjustment to changes re- quired by trade, in general, and trade with developing countries, in particular. Even here the focus is on imports of manufactured goods, and only a few examples of particular policies are considered. Furthermore, the underlying case for adjustment rather than for protectionism is not examined, there being many excellent recent discussions, for example Blackhurst, Marian and Tumlir (1977 and 1978), World Bank (1978), Balassa (May 1978), and OECD (1979 and June 1979). Discussion here is limited to pointing to the relatively small impact of imports from developing countries - in fact, the role of these imports as a scapegoat for much deeper problems. B. Definitions For our purposes an adjustment policy is defined as any policy or set of policies that makes possible-the acceptance of, rather than resistance to, market penetration by the exports of developing countries in developed-countries. This is an extremely bro-ad definition as far as means are concerned, but is a narrow one as far as the goal is concerned. Since, as Ohlin (1975, p.8) points out,'the meaning of 'adjustment assistance' is not self-evident', it will not be a surprise that other definitions exist. The closest to ours is UNCTAD's (1978, Summary and Conclusions, para.(ii)):"adjustment assistance programmes should pave the way for further import liberalization for the competitive products of developing countries." However, this definition is mcre restrictive, since it assumes assistance and also concentrates on liberalization, rather than the avoid- ance of new protection. Fels (1974, pp. 250-1) states that adjustment assistance
 - 4 - aims at "assisting the rehabilitation or compensation of those who have been put at a disadvantage as a result of increased import competition. In doing so, it involves a shift from the provision of security by actual or potential trade limitations to security by assisting restructuring." This definition focuses on a specific means of bringing about adjustment, namely, assistance to displaced factors of production, but is broader than ours to the extent that it covers all imports. Miles' definition (1975, p.15) is restricted to industrial policies: "The term adjustment assistance is customarily taken to mean specific policy measures directed towards facilitating the adaptation of domestic industries to import competition." It will be useful for the purposes of the discussion to make certain distinctions. In the first place, an adjustment policy will be- seen to work by reducing the social costs, redistributing the private costs and in these ways increasing the political acceptability of change. Adjustment policies will be an alternative to purely defensive measures. Some policies are aimed largely at increasing the efficiency with which resources are transferred in the economy; others, and compensation above all, are aimed almost exclusively at redistribu- ting private costs and making protection less politically desirable. It may also be useful to see adjustment policy as including measures to adapt to change, to accelerate change and to anticipate change. "Adjustment assistance", however, is more narrow than adjustment policy. It is perfectly possible to imagine a success- ful adjustment policy (namely, reliance on the market), which involves no assistance at all. Thus, adjustment assistance is taken to refer to policies involving actual government expenditure. While the criterion for evaluating the success of policy is a narrow one and relates to trade with developing countries, policies need not be. Even when judged solely from the point of view of the developing countries' exports, policies need not be strictly trade-related. For this reason it will be necessary
 - 5 - to examine whether a particular policy can,- must, or should be restricted to change created by trade, or rather whether it should be seen as a general measure potentially beneficial or harmful from our more hiarrow point of view. C. Outline and Summary of Conclusions a. The Context for Adjustment to Imports from Developing Countries A period of slow growth and high unemployment is one in which adjustment to the impact of new overseas competition is particularly difficult. Some protectionist bias against imports from developing countries could be seen even in the boom years of the 1960s and early 1970s, but it seems to have become worse since 1974. Moreover, evidence of declining flexibility and increasing inability to operate Keynesian macroeconomic policies emerged during the 1960s, and these tendencies also worsened, to the extent that they did not cause, the malaise of the period-after 1974. Faced with what seemed to be unmanageable problems, an increasing number of governments resorted to short-term, selective, and defensive measures to shore up existing production; of these measures discriminatory protec- tion against imports from developing countries was among the foremost. Indeed, these imports have played something of the role of scapegoat in recent years. A detailed analysis of the problems of the developed countries is beyond the scope of this paper. Two points do, however, emerge. The first is that we can at least look for policies that might reduce the bias against imports, in spite of the generally unfavourable environment. Moreover, some adjustment policies are inherently general and will, therefore, contribute both to our imme- diate goal and to the wider one of increasing the flexibility of the industrial economies. The second point is that the various analyses of the overall problems of industrial countries, and the specific issue of adjustment to imports, differ fundamentally in their starting points. Some commentators have taken protectionist positions, and their influence, while not yet decisive in any major country, has been considerable. However, even among those who favour adjustment to trade there
 - 6 - are major differences both of analysis and recommendation. Some authors see the entire problem as the consequence of "overmighty" government, and recommend, both for the specific issue of adjustment to trade and for the wider goal of effi- cient growth, a policy of much diminished intervention of all kinds. Others stress the inherent defects of the market, and consider that it is only very recently that government intervention has become counter-productive. They stress the need to move to "positive adjustment" policies, which include a host of general inter- ventions, especially in factor markets, to improve the workings of the market. Yet others stress the failures of the market mechanism itself, and tend to see the solution as direct government involvement in sectoral planning and industrial restructuring, taking into account the particular goal of adjusting to imports from developing countries. These differences, and related differences among countries, determine in some measure the choice of acceptable adjustment policies. b. The Adjustment Problem and the Goals of Adjustment Policy Transitional social costs created by imports are the result of market imperfections and most analyses indicate that they are modest. These transitional costs may even be negative if account is taken of the growing employment opportunities created elsewhere. The real issue is that of the dis- tribution of private costs, since there is evidence of large transfers through protection to sector- or location-specific factors in the short- to medium-run. The lack of adequate compensation, combined with the receptivity of the political system to protectionist pleas, explains the prevalence of protection. There is some reason to believe that industries directly affected by import competition from developing countries are likely to find survival parti- cularly difficult, and that their failure will impose high costs on some of the owners of sector-specific factors. All the evidence on the numbers of workers displaced by imports from developing countries indicates that these are modest, especially in relation to those displaced by productivity growth. One recent analys
 indicates that in gross terms only about 3 percent of the total labor force in manu- facturing in industrialized countries might be theoretically displaced by imports from developing countries between 1976 and 1986, while net change would be zero. Almost half of the workers affected seem to be women, and there is some evidence that the effect would be concentrated in poorer regions. The costs to workers in the tradition- ally vulnerable industries do not seem to be particularly high when comparison is made with industries where-unskilled and semi-skilled workers receive much more generous wages (such as automobiles and steel). However, there is some evidence that a sig- nificant proportion of the workers displaced by imports from developing countries do become permanently unemployed. There is no reason to suppose that these imports will have any effect on the overall relative level of wages in the foreseeable future. Turning to the political dimension, it appears that the industry associations representing capitalists and managers, rather than organized labor, are the decisive lobby for these industries. Moreover, with the possible exception of textiles, where the large fibre producers have thrown their weight alongside that of the host of smaller textile and clothing firms, the lobbies of industries affected by imports from developing countries do not appear particularly powerful, at least until they started to affect the steel industry - if only marginally. What may be more important is the general lack of any strong pressures against the use of protection against imports from developing countries, -the main differences with the case of imports from the major developed countries being the fear of retaliation, in the latter, and the widespread acceptance that low-cost imports are "unfair", in the former. Adjustment policy is, in economic terms, aimed at lowering the social costs, largely through a reduction in the duration of unemployment, and redistribut- ing the private costs. The sorts of policies thought appropriate tend to depend on the ideologies outlined above. However, the key aim of any adjustment policy is to make acceptance of the particular change more politically feasible, and all alternatives have to be evaluated in this light.

An Evaluation of Existing Policies What will work and is appropriate obviously depends on the circumstances, traditions and ideologies of individual countries, and in the case of Europe of groups of countries. The following questions should be kept in mind: Is the country generally market-oriented or interventionist? Is the interventionism forward-looking or defensive? Does there exist a comprehensive and generous welfare state, likely to make redundant any further assistance at least to displaced workers? Is trade a large part of the economy, or can its effects be readily separated out? Is there noticeably greater resistance to trade-related changes than to others? Differences in these respects between the United States, Europe and Japan explain the first's reliance on a trade-related adjustment assistance program largely aimed at providing compensation to workers, the second's reliance on a wide range of general policy measures combined with (frequently defensive) industry-specific interventions, and the last's emphasis on a strategy of sectoral forward planning. It is impossible to summarize at a reasonable length the discussion of the microeconomic policies that can be viewed as conducive to adjustment. However, three conclusions can be drawn: the first is that many of-the interven- tions which are supposed to help adjustment - industrial restructuring, for example - are, in fact, largely defensive. The distinction between defensive and more positive orientations cuts across those among the different immediate goals of individual policies. Thus, industrial policies can be defensive or aimed at achieving efficient change and the same applies to regional or manpower policies. A second point is that the various kinds of intervention designed to make markets work better can consist either of direct attempts to remove existing distortions or of subsidies to offset their effects. It is particularly when failures are thought to be the spontaneous result of market forces and not open to direct poli- tical action that subsidies are most readily used. The danger here is that even
 -9- "spontaneous" distortions do not occur independently of government action to offset their effects. Thus, inability to achieve either regional mobility or wage flexibility for labor may be increased by income security, regional and manpower policies designed to offset the consequences of just those rigidities. Finally, while an orientation towards the survival of existing vulnerable industry is unlikely to prove other than counter-productive, and the use of emergency "safeguard'" protection should, therefore, be tightly controlled, carefully de- signed general industria]., regional and-manpower policies can be useful in improving the workings of the economy, and income maintenance and compensation programs can help to redistribute the burden. However, none of these general policies has, at least in the context of low growth and high unemployment, assuaged protectionist pressures, perhaps because of the political role of owners of sector-specific factors subject to large and uncompensated windfall losses. It is because of the essentially political nature of the adjustment problem that emphasis must be placed on policies designed to help those affected- by a particular source of change, namely imports. What is then provided is a visible alternative to the often futile attempt to preserve the status quo. Thus, the impact of trade can be used as a criterion for assistance to owrkers of factors employed in aff,cted firms and to the regions in which they are located. Programs designed to provide especially high compensation to workers displaced by trade, or to assist firms to restructure their operations in those circumstances, exist in the United States, Canada and the Netherlands. They face the general problem that delays and uncertainty are inevitable when benefits are provided only to those already affected by a particular source of change. The consequence tends to be that benefits come too late to be relevant to decision makers at the time of lay-off or contraction. Moreover, the-costs borne by the owners of relatively sector-specific factors are quite inadequately compensated in these programs.
 - 10 - Thus, the actual political benefits are modest. These programs also tend to suffer from the drawback of trying to keep firms in business instead of compen- sating them for closure, and they may in this way maintain the protectionist lobby in being. The problem of delay, in particular, can be dealt with by using an industry, rather than a specific source of change, as the organizing principle for assistance. There is always the problem that the boundary of an industry is arbitrary, but at least in this way a host of firms can be-identified as eligible almost at a stroke. The greatest practical disadvantage is that, instead of using the industry as a vehicle for identifying those eligible for compensation, manpower or community assistance, there is a natural tendency to attempt to shore up the industry itself. Furthermore, there can be great injustice if the early victims are uncompensated because an industry-wide assistance program does not yet exist. d. Towards Improved Adjustment Policies Within the context of a market economy compensation of those affected by imports seems to be the only feasible direct alternative to protection. How- ever, estimates of the size of the transfers to factors employed in protected industries indicate that full compensation is not feasible. What might be managed, however, is lump sum compensation of those who leave an industry, combined with a long-term but clearly announced program of gradual liberalization or strictly time-bound emergency protection. The relevant point is that in the long term almost all factors of production are mobile, and transfers to them from protection correspondingly negligible. In effect, the compensation program would benefit the more marginal factors of production and the (strictly controlled) protection would sustain the incomes of those who have few alternative opportunities in the short to medium term. However, if such protection were to be provided, it would be important to ensure that no niew factors were attracted into the industry because
 - 11 - of it. Programs of this kind could be provided in the context of decisions to liberalize specific imports or when it is determined that a given industry is suffering injury from imports. The existence of a general program to provide compensation to those whose factors of production are employed in firms which are affected by imports, on the lines of the adjustment assistance program of the United States, would provide a useful source of information on when an industry was facing growing difficulties. In countries where trade is a much larger pro- portion of GNP than in the United States such a program could be oriented just to imports from developing countries. However, if no program to help those involved in particular input-affected firms exists, it will be necessary to establish a careful monitoring system to identify the problems of an entire industry early. Of more general policies designed to improve the flexibility of an economy, the following seem to be potentially useful: regional policies that exclude 'ronl 'ncentives industries that are vulnerable to imports, concentrate on the provision of general infrastructure, and, above all, lead to a richer endowment in poorer regions of highly-skilled labor; manpower policies designed to offset the many taxes now imposed on employment, including replacement of some of the conditional payments in social security systems with lump sums;-government support for training in firms and direct provision of such training; reduction in the obstacles to worker mobility inherent in many current practices in housing and pensions, in particular; assistance to industrial research and development, but not direct support to senescent industry with the - usually futile - aim of buying it back to viability; and, in certain cases, government support for the dynamic industries of the future on the successful model of Japan. Some commentators on adjustment adopt a different position, in which general support for the market process is replaced by sectoral planning, or even planning at a national levelswith the aim of adapting to imports. This approach seems unlikely to work, with sector-specific plan8 being more likely to engender
 - 12 - well-articulated pleas frjr protection that antything else, and being diffliult to implement as well. Similarly, there seems to be little point in attempting to anticipate the structural changes that will be needed and attempting to impose them by fiat. The willingness to adjust tather than to resist requires an initer- national consensus. Trade policies will need modification in a number of countries simultaneously, since otherwise the adjustment capacity of one can be swamped by the trade diversion created by the protectionism of others. Developing countries, for theic part, need to explore ways to raise the perceived political cost of protection and to persuade the industrialized countries that adjustment is in their own interests and not a sacrifice of them to a purely charitable cause.
 - 13 - II. THE OVERALL CONTEXT FOR ADJUSTMENT TO IMPORTS FROM DEVELOPING COUNTRIES The ability and willingness of the developed countries to absorb increased imports from the developing countries is determined in substantial measure by their overall economic situation. Without the full employment of labour and the ability to adjust speedily to economic change, strong resistance is likely to be the main response to the emergence of new competitors. It is, therefore, impossible to consider the problem of adjustment to the imports from developing countries without at least a brief analysis of this overall context. Indeed, it would be perfectly defensible to argue that the problem created by the developing countries' exports is solely a manifestation of the larger issue of macroeconomic imbalance. Blackhurst, Marian and Tumlir (1978) set out to do just this, their argument being, in essence, that the current overall problems of the developed countries and the resistance to exports from developing countries derive from the same roots and require the same cure. While the overall context is important for our more immediate concern and merits consideration, it will not be the main-focus of our treatment of the ad- justment problem. One reason is that there exists already a very large body of literature on the macroeconomic problems of the developed countries,quite apart from the reams written on the theoretical basis of macroeconomic policy. Moreover, the macroeconomic environment and its microeconomic causes and con- sequences must be taken largely as. given. There is little that can be done about the problem in the near future (except perhaps for avoiding making it worse by resort to protectionism). Thus, we are still left with the major
 - 14 - question of whether, given this environment, policies can be adopted that will facilitate, cr at least not prevent, a rather modest inflow of exports from developing countries. This leads to our view, subsequently elaborated, that the failure of adjustment to imports from developing countries is not determined in any simple way by the overall environment or by failures of general policy. There has always been a certain discrimination against change that derives from the emergence of new competitors in world markets. For that very reason, there may exist policies that can at least reduce that discrimination (or even promote these adjustments). This is not to deny the existence of some constraints at an overall level, but merely to indicate the existence of room for manouevre, which might be of some value. Thus we are searching for policies that may help to reduce the bias against change brought about by trade, in general, and imports from developing countries in particular. If, as turns out to be the case, some of these can help to im- prove the overall flexibility of the industrial economies and permit faster growth and more efficient use of capacity, they are, so to speak, "twice blessed." Compensation and Income Maintenance In a market economy compensation is the obvious way of dealing with the problem of the unequal distribution of the benefits and costs arising from any particular change. If compensation could be truly "lump-sum" and have no effect on efficiency, an economic problem would not be created. However, it cannot be, and thus there are costs associated with any given scheme of compensation. This brings out a key difference between compensation as an
 - 149 - adjustment policy and those we have already considered: whereas the other adjustment measures can have direct economic benefits and reduce the social costs of adjustment (although the reverse is probably true of many of the examples we have considered), compensation will normally affect only the private costs and political acceptability-of change. But even so, if compen- sation is a policy alternative to protection, which itself imposes efficiency costs, it can increase aggregate, unweighted,social welfare via its effect on policy choice. This emphasizes the importance of allowing for political effects in judging the economic consequences of policy in controversial areas like trade (Corden 1974, p.112). What is the relationship between a compensation program and one designed to provide income security? If perfect compensation could be provided for all losses, perfect income security would- also be available. However, in a world of uncertainty the two concepts diverge. Income security is provided by insurance: the recipient is guaranteed a certain level of income irrespective of the state of the world. Since one cannot know the state of the world in any period except by experiencing it, this entails periodic payment to bring the level of income up to dhe desired level. If the insurance scheme guaranteed the recipient his expected income, he would be fully compensated for change but in a way that removed all incentive to work. The problem is, of course, that states of the world are not independent of action, which in turn will be affected by the knowledge that the initial expected income is guaranteed irr- espective of action. For this reason all actual income security schemes fall well short of guaranteeing original expected income and thus do not compensate
 - 150 - fully for economic change. In a world of uncertainty compensation might be defined as that sum which leaves the recipient indifferent between maintaining his original expected income in his original employment and the best income he can expect from new employment, taking into account the cost of search and any insurance and welfare payments available in the interim period. It will be clear that such compensation does not provide security because no allowance is made for the possibiliity of being wrong about the income one can expect to obtain and the costs of search. However, it is also worth noting that the compensation sum is likely to be larger than the present value of the difference between the two income streams to the extent that the recipient is not in- different to risk. d. i. The argument is that owners of capital are expected to bear risks and that if in their personal capacities they become poor, the general welfare system will take care of them. However, there do exist reasons for compensating capitalists. An economic argument is that the state shares in gains through its taxation, but it shares in losses only if a

Thus, small, undiversified companies are at a relative disadvantage from this point of view. If firms are extremely risk- averse and this prevents them from undertaking projects which ard valuable from the social point -of view, there is also a case for compensating some losses. However, the major argument for compensation is, as we have noted, a political one, namely, the strength of opposition by the owners of fixed capital to trade liberalization and the need to buy this opposition out. Industry-Oriented Adjustment Programs By an "industry-oriented adjustment program" we mean much more than just assistance to an industry. What is also included is help to factors of production who are forced to leave and foreigners for which a particular industry is vital. Thus the industry is just the organizing principle for assistance as was trade in the previous section, without there being any necessary commit- ment to its survival. Providing assistance to those affected by an industry's decline offers certain substantial advantages. In the first place, eligibility can be "precertified" by looking at the overall circumstances of the industry, (for example, output, sales, employment, exports and imports), without bothering about the situation of individual firms. This can expedite administration. In the second place, protection is given to an entire range of producers and, consequently, pressure for protection will be assuaged only by a program that benefits an equally wide range of firms, whether or not they would be eligible for firm-specific adjustment assistance. However, there are also some dis- advantages. One is the likelihood that an industry-wide "adjustment program" will be no more than a last-ditch defense. Another is the inevitable arbitrari- ness in the definition of an industry, and of who is in it. There is also the question of whether it is desirable to assist flourishing firms in a vulnerable industry. Despite these various drawbacks the approach has merits. Consequently, we examine a few examples of such programs, focussing largely on those which seem to be clearly aimed at expediting adjustment in industries vulnerable to trade.

In this case, whether the program is successful or not, the result is likely to be a failure to accept greatly increased imports, and indeed growing protection. Thus, it is essential that any funds for modernization or re-equipment be used only for those sorts of investments that are compatible with growing imports. This, in turn, means that such funds can be justified only if the government has made it clear that protection will not be granted to save the industry (if subsidized capital to vulnerable industry can be justified at all). The second lesson is that the industry-focus does indeed simplify administration. This is obvious when, as in the case of the coal and steel industries in Europe, one has a few large establishments, generally of great importance to a particular area. However, the same also seems to be true even of such unconcentrated industries as textiles. B. Adjustment Policies for Market-Oriented Interventionist Countries Most individual countries are interventionist in varying degrees, and most are also protectionist to some extent. The efficient way to deal with the latter problem is to introduce a compensation program on the lines we have suggested. With various modifications depending on the importance of trade and the willingness to focus exclusively on developing countries, the approach seems appropriate for almost all countries. However, it may be useful, in addition, to employ positive policies designed to bring social and private costs closer together if it is believed that existing distortions can indeed be removed by government action, either through subsidization or other means. Such policies are essentially economy-wide, and, to the extent that they are successful, all adjustment will become more efficient. We begin by examining the relationship between these policies and the specific problem of trade with developing countries. We then examine whether the policies can be use- fully incorporated into a trade-oriented program. It should be noted that when what is recommended is the removal of existing policies that create the distortion, the ideologue of the pure free market will, of course, concur.

E. Conclusion The aim of adjustment policy is to lower social costs, redistribute private costs and increase the political acceptability of a specific change, namely, that created by import competition. Broadly speaking this can be achieved by compensating those who lose and by reducing the social costs associated with change. The last, in turn, can be secured by policy to offset the differences between social and private costs with the aim of
 - 217 - improving the working of the market or by more or less radical policies to suppress or substitute for the market. In the context of the developed countries the market is likely to be replaced by comprehensive fact-finding, followed by negotiation about what change to accept, how to achieve it, and who is to bear the costs. Compensation of those adversely affected by the change is, in our view, the corner-stone of any policy that aims at adjustment rather than protection. It is clear that there are good arguments against compensation, but it is important to recognize that the pilicy is not being recommended in vacuo. Protection already exists or is likely to be increasingly used. Given the existence of the distortion and the implicit admission that the incomes of those affected should be maintained, compensation is the obvious alternative. Compensation cannot be given to everyone. It would be vastly expensive and impossible to allocate. Instead, compensation in the form of an unconditional lump sum should be offered to those who intend to quit the industry. The sum to be offered need not equal the full private costs of departure, partly because some possibility of exit exists even under protection. For workers, the costs of job search, of a period of unemployment and of reduced earnings in a new job would have to be taken into account. For firms choosing liquidation or plant closure, the closest approximation to reasonable compensation seems to be a proportion of the difference petween the book value of assets (allowing for depreciation and inflation) and their current market value. Where the costs faced by fixed factors are high, emergency protection with a time limit or slow liberalization may be necessary.

The best approach is a trade-related assistance program, under which firms in certain specified situations and their workers would be entitled to compensation. The program could be triggered in one of three ways: either by a decision to liberalize imports of currently protected goods; or by a finding of injury to a range of producers of certain goods; or by application from individual firms or groups of workers not coming under the first two. There are certain major advantages to a trade-related program which permits assistance both to a "precertified" industry and to individual firms. One is that assistance to firms will serve as an early warning system which, along with monitoring of trends, will make it easier to deter- mine when a whole industry is coming into difficulties. Secondly, it will be easier to ensure consistency both within and across industries. Thus there may be a general scale for all workers, depending only on pay, age, and seniority. In addition, those who lose their jobs before an industry-wide program is declared would also receive benefits, and the same applies to the reduction in the value of capital. Finally, the machinery to deal with new problems would exist, and would not-have to be created in each individual case. The alternative is to have a series of industry-specific programs, in which case it will be very important to monitor development carefully, since otherwise great inequities within industries will arise. Trade-related programs are infeasible in most smaller, more open countries. For that reason it may be desirable to focus exclusively on trade with developing countries. doc.repnme: Adjustment policies and problems in developed countries
doc.abstracts: This study examines the problem posed by the need to adjust to imports from developing countries. It begins with an attempt to define the terms of adjustment and adjustment policy. The overall context within which adjustment has to occur is then discussed, and attention is drawn both to the unfavorable macroeconomic environment and to the bias against changes brought about by imports from developing countries. The theory of adjustment costs and their political implications is examined, followed by a review of the evidence on the exact impact of the exports of manufactures from developing countries and on the nature of the protectionist response as a political phenomenon. This leads to a definition of the possible forms and goals of adjustment policy. The effectiveness of existing policies is reviewed, immediately following a discussion of the relevant differences between major developed countries. Finally conclusions are drawn about what improved adjustment policy might consist of in different country contexts.
